results.title: Forward a century
results.creator_credit: Stuart Legg, Basic Films and J.B. Napier-Bell
results.brief_description: A film made for the Festival of Britain surveying the nation’s achievements during the past 100 years, a note on contemporary conditions, and some indication of possible advances within the next 100 years. Old prints and engravings of life in Victorian ships, financial exchanges and Parliament, customs of the different classes, slums and other manifestations of poverty, all seen against a commentary explaining features of the period’s social, industrial, scientific and political history. Changes since that time illustrated by views of the 1951 Festival and of accomplishments in various technological fields, with emphasis on the increasing concern for human welfare. A number of scientists suggest possible sources of energy and power in 2051.

results.title: Forum of protest
results.creator_credit: Richard Linning, Gary Cunningham and HSV7 Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Week”.
Prompted by the statement by the then Victorian Premier, Sir Henry Bolte, to the effect that there would be no State Parliamentary House of Review within a generation, this television current affairs report dedicates itself to the history and protocol of the Victorian Legislative Council as well as the architectural features of its chambers. A fairly dry “talking heads” program.

results.title: Forty thousand horsemen
results.creator_credit: Famous Feature Films and Charles Chauvel
results.brief_description: Forty thousand horsemen is set during World War 1 and deals with the exploits of the Australian Light Horse in Palestine. Chauvel’s uncle, who led the actual charge at Beersheba, was the inspiration for this acclaimed historical recreation. The film is unapologetically intensly nationalistic, viewed through the eyes of three Anzacs, Red (Grant Taylor), Larry (Pat Twohill) and Jim (Chips Rafferty). This internationally successful film established Chips Rafferty’s laconic bushman stereotype for which he became renown and established Chauvel as a world class director.

results.title: Forty million shoes: a report on Brazil
results.creator_credit: Douglas Leiterman, Cliff Solway and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Describes the gulf between the rich and poor of Brazil, and the difficulty of escaping the peasants’ trap of working for the land-owner. Also discusses the inevitability of change in Brazil by “democratic” or “totalitarian” means and the possibility of a solution being provided by either “free enterprise” and foreign capital, or by the Brazilian “communist” land leagues.

results.title: Forty guns = 40 guns
results.creator_credit: Samuel Fuller, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Globe Enterprises
results.brief_description: A classic example of the Western genre, written, directed and produced by maverick Samuel Fuller. Shot in black and white and “cinemascope” this lush film is filled with all you would expect from a Western: guns, fancy horse riding, showdowns and a bit of romance. The tough town femme-fatale Jessica Drummond (Barbara Stanwyck) has a posse of forty hired guns that make her the de facto leader of the County. She falls in love with a Marshall (Barry Sullivan) who arrives to restore law and order with tensions building up to a showdown.

results.title: Fortune telling
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
Paddington Bear visits the fair and consults a fortune teller who advises that his future is rather clouded. Written by Michael Bond, animation by Ivor Wood.

results.title: Fortress Goolengook
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Fortress Australia: the secret bid for the Atomic Bomb [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Peter Butt and Rob McAuley
results.brief_description: How close Australia came during the 1950s and ‘60s to creating our own weapons of mass destruction is revealed in this edifying documentary. During the secrecy of the Cold War era, Australia’s Atomic Energy Commission, run by Sir Phillip Baxter, was set up to push an atomic weaponry solution to fortify Australian defences. Now uncovered “Top Secret” documents from the era demonstrate the machinations of government and our tentative relations with the Allies when it came to the nuclear question. Research reactors, guided missile test sites and “The Bomb” at Woomera are all discussed, as is “Operation Blowdown”, a secret event where 50 Tons of TNT was exploded in Far North Queensland to illustrate the possible effect of a nuclear strike in jungle terrain and its implications for foot soldiers. Narrated by Robyn Williams. Part of Film Australia’s National Interest Program series, produced with assistance from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

results.title: Fortress
results.creator_credit: Raymond Menmuir, Crawford Productions and Arch Nicholson
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Gabrielle Lord. A teacher and her class of nine students are kidnapped by four masked men and held for ransom. The victims plot to escape by outwitting their captors.
